newsitem.title: UK: Candidate to replace Major urges UK IGC referendum.
newsitem.headline: Candidate to replace Major urges UK IGC referendum.

text.p: John Redwood, a candidate in next month's race for the leadership of Britain's Conservative Party, called on Friday for a referendum on the outcome of new month's European Union Intergovernmental Conference.

Redwood said Prime Minister Tony Blair, in the Dutch town of Noordwijk for an informal meeting with fellow EU heads of government, would be discussing agenda items which are "part of the Franco-German plan to create a new country called Europe".
In a statement, he added: "Given the surrender of power he (Blair) is likely to make, he should immediately offer the British people a referendum. We should have our say about what he proposes."
Redwood, a former cabinet minister who challenged John Major for the party leadership in 1995, is generally regarded as the most right-wing and Eurosceptical of the six candidates to replace Major.

The party's 164 MPs will vote on June 10 for a new leader. If no candidate gets the necessary backing prescribed by party rules, as seems likely, there will be a second ballot a week later. -- London Newsroom +44 171 5427767
